body:
Well, I investigated the source code and it seems there is no other way, than fork lodash and set fp module as

```javascript
var _ = require('lodash/lodash.min').runInContext();
module.exports = require('lodash/fp/_baseConvert')(_, _, { cap: false });
```

or event better change the `convert` method to not cap by default, which will uncap also all cherry picks.

Then set Webpack alias for `lodash/fp` to this custom module and pray for stable implementation in library. Converting methods globally after library declaration seems impossible.

Webpack aliasing is not necessary, but lodash/fp eslint rules works only for `lodash/fp` module name, so eslint checks will stop working when import point to different location.

Babel plugin sees aliased location, but checks name in `package.json` or can use `id` configuration option.

I'm not sure if want to take such burden, but I'm very unhappy with caping behaviour ðŸ˜ž

PR #4718 demonstrates how one could make default options global configurable. 

Object `defaultOptions` lives in the scope of `_baseConvert` and could be overriden from the outside via function `_baseConvert.setDefaultOptions`. Calling this function very early in the dependency tree (before any other import of `lodash/fp`) would override default options. But I understand this is not transparent and generally, not a good solution.

I think about the rationale behind `cap`. It seems to me like a design flaw. Using `unary` is much more simple than `map.convert({ cap: false })` all the time or than use pairs like

```JavaScript
pipe(
  toPairs,
  map(([key, value]) => ....)
  fromPairs
)(inputObj)
```

which produces two unnecessary iterations and creates N*2 redundant tuples (iteratee must also return a tuple) :-(

Please, if there is any drive towards lodash@5, consider don't cap iteratees by default.
